thread.title: Florida attractions in October: Astronomy, disasters and Spanish colonization
thread.title_full: Florida attractions in October: Astronomy, disasters and Spanish colonization

author: Matt Mauney
title: Florida attractions in October: Astronomy, disasters and Spanish colonization
text:
0 
The family-friendly exhibit incorporates three themes – exploration, risk and scientist stories – and is broken into four areas – origins, asteroids, comets as well as impacts and risks. 
Guests will gather data about asteroids and comets as they climb into a "spaceship" and blast off to the asteroid belt and Jupiter. They will also get a glimpse of what it's like to be an astronomer, using tools like a blink comparator and running tests to examine a collection of rocks. 
Risk is a big part of the exhibit, as guests will learn about three major impact stories from different periods of history – the Chicxulub crater (dinosaurs), Barringer Meteor Crater and the 1908 Tunguska Event above the surface of Siberia. 
A Google Maps display will let guests see what would happen if a comet or asteroid hit their town. They will also have the chance to "save Earth" by diverting a "rubble pile" asteroid while learning the role gravity plays. 
And clips from blockbuster disaster movies will be evaluated to see if Hollywood got science right. 
Who says science can't be fun? 
For more astronomy fun, visitors can opt to upgrade to a combo ticket which includes viewings of "Hubble 3D" and "Space Station 3D" in MODS' IMAX 3D theater. 
For more information, visit www.mods.org . 
First Colony: Our Spanish Origins at Florida Museum 
You're no longer able to see a T. rex Named Sue at the Florida Museum of Natural History, but a new traveling exhibit is coming to Gainesville in October. 
First Colony: Our Spanish Origins details the colonization of St. Augustine in 1565. The historic site became our country's first enduring European settlement, long before Jamestown. 
The exhibit will show how St. Augustine became America's original "melting pot," featuring a multicultural society including Spaniards, free and enslaved Africans and Native Americans. 
First Colony opens Oct. 17 at the Florida Museum. The exhibit is currently on display at Government House Museum in St. Augustine. 
For more information, visit www.flmnh.ufl.edu . 
West wing reopening at MOAS 
The west wing of the Museum of Arts & Sciences in Daytona Beach will reopen in October after being closed for reconstruction. 
The renovated wing will be the new home for the museum's giant ground sloth skeleton, as well as the Cuban Foundation and the African artifacts exhibit. 
For more information, visit www.moas.org .
